name: Gerald Marvin Weinberg
background: American computer scientist, author, and teacher specializing in the psychology and anthropology of software development. PhD from University of Michigan (1963). Worked on IBM Project Mercury (1959-1963). Consultant at Weinberg & Weinberg since 1969. Visiting professor at University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Binghamton University, Columbia University. Authored over 40 books and 400 articles. Key awards: J.-D. Warnier Prize (1993), Stevens Award (2000), Luminary Award (2010).

principles.name: 1. Systems Thinking
principles.description: Organizations and software development are complex systems; quality emerges from observing patterns, feedback loops, and interactions rather than isolated parts. (Quality Software Management Vol. 1: Systems Thinking)
principles.falsification: When 1. systems thinking leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: 2. Psychology of Programming
principles.description: Human factors like egoless programming, cognitive biases, and team dynamics profoundly impact software quality. (The Psychology of Computer Programming)
principles.falsification: When 2. psychology of programming leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: 3. Quality Before Metrics
principles.description: True quality requires understanding context and observing behaviors; avoid premature optimization or flawed measurement. (Quality Software Management series)
principles.falsification: When 3. quality before metrics leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: 4. Consulting Secrets
principles.description: Advice succeeds through building trust, understanding client systems, and knowing when not to advise. Law of Twins: Most efforts yield no significant results. (The Secrets of Consulting)
principles.falsification: When 4. consulting secrets leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
